instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi, have a customers Macbook pro retina 15" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A [LIST=1]
[*]I have pp3v42(green and yellow light) on the charger.
[*]No water damage, computer just shut off for customer
[*]L7030 > Pin 2 outputs 1.5v.
[*]<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> pin2 only 16.5v.
[*]<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pin3(AC IN 3.8v)
[/LIST]
update: it seems <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is shorted. The IC its burning hot. So it must be a short on the IC, or could it be something else shorting it to ground?

Any suggestions pls? thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Remove <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and see if the short goes away.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> pin2 only 16.5v."
No voltage on pin2???
That means burnt resistor; never saw this...
Check for short <CAPACITOR>C7021</CAPACITOR>/22 and pin 28/<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.
Also one of <CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR>-36 can be shorted...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
1. I changed the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and I got the green/orange light back. Might have been a bad <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Because it was working when i started troubleshoot.
2. Still NO fan spin though.

Ok, i will check what 2informaticos said above. and give you update on that

threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> pin2 only 16.5v."

No voltage on pin2???
[COLOR=#FF0000]only 194.6 millivolt.[/COLOR]

That means burnt resistor; never saw this...
[COLOR=#FF0000]There are more places now on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> line which is not showing correct reading. Its like te voltage is confused and cant zone in on a reading. I continue the trouleshoot the parts not showing correct voltage and post them here.[/COLOR]

Check for short <CAPACITOR>C7021</CAPACITOR>/22 and pin 28/<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.
[COLOR=#FF0000]pin 28/<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> Showing 228 millivolt. same thign there, DMM cant read properly. and <CAPACITOR>C7021</CAPACITOR>/22 same thing.[/COLOR]

Also one of <CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR>-36 can be shorted...
[COLOR=#FF0000]Same[/COLOR][COLOR=#FF0000] thing, the volt fluctuates [/COLOR][COLOR=#FF0000]same[/COLOR][COLOR=#FF0000] as [/COLOR][COLOR=#FF0000]i[/COLOR][COLOR=#FF0000] stated above. Strange! I will try to reflow the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and see if that improves the Voltage [/COLOR][COLOR=#FF0000]ralls[/COLOR][COLOR=#FF0000].

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"No voltage on pin2???"
Mea culpa, read it as "No voltage on pin1???"

I asked to check for short on several points.
That means diode mode (red probe to ground), NOT voltage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7021</CAPACITOR> = 0.520 (Diode mode)
<CAPACITOR>C7022</CAPACITOR> = 0.525 (diode mode)
<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> pin28 = 0.525 (diode mode)
<CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR> = 0.513 (diode mode)
<CAPACITOR>C7036</CAPACITOR> = 0.516 (diode mode)
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> (pin 2, im ttaking diode mode from testpoint which is connected to R702 pin2) I get 0.518 (diodemode)

I still have green/orange light, but no fan spin..

What should I check next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
What voltage you get on <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> (pin 5) and L7030?
Post resistance to ground on L7030 too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> (pin 5) = 16,1v
L7030 = 290.4mv on both pins
resistance to ground on L7030(pin1) = 50 ohm

The transistor <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> is super hot, burning hot so 100% its shorted. Im going to change it and let u know..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> is not shorted; you get different input/output voltages!!!

Remove F7040/41 and check which side remains the low value (50 ohms) to ground.

I removed the <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>, added another <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> from another board. but not I put back the first <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>.. and suddenly the L7770 is getting super hot.. I might have screwed it up more by removing and putting back the <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>.. problem now is the COIL (L7770)

threads.message:

Be sure to solder <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> properly...

threads.message:

Which is the correct way to measure Resistance to ground on the coil L7030?
Because i get two different readings when connecting the Black probe to ground compare to Red probe on ground.

thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Is OK, post both values.
But I asked you to check that on both side of F7040/41 fuses; after removed them.
If problem remains on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> side, is not complicate.
If the low value is on system side, then you can expect troubles...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I removed the both fuses

Resistance mode.

F7040 pin 2 = 35 k ohm

F7041 pin2 = 35k ohm


Diode mode:
F7040 pin 1 = 0.472
F7040 pin 2 = 0.035

F7041 pin1 = 0.472
F7041 pin2 = 0-035

When trying to measure resistance. The DMM, sometimes has hardtime to make a reading. Sometimes showing K ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Maybe i screwed something up when removing the Mosfet earlier. When using wick, (following Louis examples) the solder only get smeared out all over the joints. So the 3 Source pins are connected now with solder. But they shoudl be according to schematic(So thats not an issue I suppose?) Not the best practice, dont understand how Louis manage to do it. Need to find a better solution to wick pads. I checked the pins on mosfet with continuity mode and they are not connected /shorted together so thats good i guess?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: if u cant help me fix, please do let me know, so i dont waste time waiting for replies..I can see you have alot of people to reply to?  i need to gets these boards fix very fast..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Macbook Pro Retina 15" Shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
We may not have the same working hours; this is not online assistance.
I try to help you, but I expect that you don't experiment the way you did.
You can get more damage on the board.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> seems to be shorted, change it now.

035 diode mode on the system side of the fuses is the problem.
That means 60-70 ohms (into ohm scale).
Now check every big coil in respect to ground.
Let see if you get the same value.
If yes, check the corresponding MOSFET to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (for that coil).

BTW, you don't need to check values on both fuses; are tied together, cannot give different values...

After replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> check if get correct voltage on L7030; fuses removed, of course.
